The fact that the lectures held
under the auspices of this. University are particularly appreciated,
not only by students, hut even by
uttIr outsiders, was evinced by the
large audiences which attended
every one of the five lectures delivered. by Prof. Josef Redlich of
the Vniversity of Vienna who was
invitzd to speak here under the
James Schouler Foundation of History. Beginning last Monday, he
spoke every day, on the broad subject of "Political Problems of Austria-Hungary," each day taking a
different section of the history of
these countries. Taking as his starting :point the beginning of Hungarian independence in 1222, the
speaker traced the constitutional
and political developments of the
three countries of Austria, Hun:
gary, and Bohemia, through the
various important reigns and dynasties down to the present day.
For example, one whole lecture
was devoted to the governmental
problems that arose during the
reign of the famous Austrian queen,
Maria Theresa, and of het no less
famous son, Joseph II. Many interesting details were brought out
which rounded out the general
points into a very instructive whole.
As a speaker, Dr. Redlich does
not make a very profound inipression, because of his English accent,
and his manner of speaking. Although his vocabulary was almost
faultless, the way he mangled some
words was enough to make an English-speaking person shudder. Besides, he would very often mumble
whole sentences in such a way that
they were wholly unintelligible to
the hearers. However, when we
take into consideration that the
speaker was a foreigner, we must
give him credit for having done as
well as he did, especially since he
did say much that was profitable to
the students of history.
Honor System at Columbia.
From present indications it would
seem that Columbia is going to follow the example of Princeton and
adopt the honor system. Agitation
has been going on for a long time,
but matters have taken a definite
course. The senior class was found
ill favor of the system. The juniors
voted for the measure 7 to i and
the sophomores declared themselves
willing to support it at the rate of
8 to 1.

Boosters,- This Way!

The Black List.

With examinations approaching
at an alarming pace, it is well to
sound a note of warning in regard
to the Black List.. Members of the
freshman class have doubtless heard
this name pronounced by members
of the upper classes with fear and
loathing. Concretely, the list represents the status of men whose
averages fall below 70 per cent.
on the list debars men from
representing the University on the
Musical Clubs or the athletic teams.
. Two months of football often
prove disastrous; it is only by solid.
patient plugging during the month
of December that football men can
Pull up their record.
With the few men that there are
at Hopkins, it is of immense importance that men of athletic ability
be available for sports in the spring
as well as in the fall. The husky
guards and tackles of the eleven
must become a part of the impregnable lacrosse defense. Fleet ends
are transformed into record-breaking dash men; halfbacks into
pitchers, and so on.
A man, therefore, who allows his
average to fall down does double
injury; to himself first, and to his
college, second.
The same may be said of musicians. With prospects for such good
clubs, it is extremely unfair to
Scovell, Lloyd, and Fulton, to have
the men over whom they have
worked blacklisted.
We appeal, then, to all who are
"on the edge," to use these precious
hours before examinations for hard,
concentrated "boning."
Not only will a man be better
off personally to have an aboveseventy average, but the men "at the
wheel," on whom the success of
college activities depend, will be
saved a tremendous, amount of

The inauguration of the Honor
System has already met with great
approval among the undergraduates, and in the keen interest
awakened lies the most potent element working for its success. If
everybody wants to make it go, it
takes no seer to prophesy its perfect consummation; and thus far
all comments, at least, have been
promising.
It is expected that these examinations will be somewhat different
from any ever before held at Hopkins; the professors will spend less
time in the examination halls, and worry.
What we say unto you, we say
during that time in the halls will
not feel obliged, through a sense unto all—work!
of duty, to keep watch. Of course

The fact that the lectures held
under the auspices of this. University are particularly appreciated,
not only by students, hut even by
uttIr outsiders, was evinced by the
large audiences which attended
every one of the five lectures delivered. by Prof. Josef Redlich of
the Vniversity of Vienna who was
invitzd to speak here under the
James Schouler Foundation of History. Beginning last Monday, he
spoke every day, on the broad subject of "Political Problems of Austria-Hungary," each day taking a
different section of the history of
these countries. Taking as his starting :point the beginning of Hungarian independence in 1222, the
speaker traced the constitutional
and political developments of the
three countries of Austria, Hun:
gary, and Bohemia, through the
various important reigns and dynasties down to the present day.
For example, one whole lecture
was devoted to the governmental
problems that arose during the
reign of the famous Austrian queen,
Maria Theresa, and of het no less
famous son, Joseph II. Many interesting details were brought out
which rounded out the general
points into a very instructive whole.
As a speaker, Dr. Redlich does
not make a very profound inipression, because of his English accent,
and his manner of speaking. Although his vocabulary was almost
faultless, the way he mangled some
words was enough to make an English-speaking person shudder. Besides, he would very often mumble
whole sentences in such a way that
they were wholly unintelligible to
the hearers. However, when we
take into consideration that the
speaker was a foreigner, we must
give him credit for having done as
well as he did, especially since he
did say much that was profitable to
the students of history.
Honor System at Columbia.
From present indications it would
seem that Columbia is going to follow the example of Princeton and
adopt the honor system. Agitation
has been going on for a long time,
but matters have taken a definite
course. The senior class was found
ill favor of the system. The juniors
voted for the measure 7 to i and
the sophomores declared themselves
willing to support it at the rate of
8 to 1.

The Black List.

With examinations approaching
at an alarming pace, it is well to
sound a note of warning in regard
to the Black List.. Members of the
freshman class have doubtless heard
this name pronounced by members
of the upper classes with fear and
loathing. Concretely, the list represents the status of men whose
averages fall below 70 per cent.
on the list debars men from
representing the University on the
Musical Clubs or the athletic teams.
. Two months of football often
prove disastrous; it is only by solid.
patient plugging during the month
of December that football men can
Pull up their record.
With the few men that there are
at Hopkins, it is of immense importance that men of athletic ability
be available for sports in the spring
as well as in the fall. The husky
guards and tackles of the eleven
must become a part of the impregnable lacrosse defense. Fleet ends
are transformed into record-breaking dash men; halfbacks into
pitchers, and so on.
A man, therefore, who allows his
average to fall down does double
injury; to himself first, and to his
college, second.
The same may be said of musicians. With prospects for such good
clubs, it is extremely unfair to
Scovell, Lloyd, and Fulton, to have
the men over whom they have
worked blacklisted.
We appeal, then, to all who are
"on the edge," to use these precious
hours before examinations for hard,
concentrated "boning."
Not only will a man be better
off personally to have an aboveseventy average, but the men "at the
wheel," on whom the success of
college activities depend, will be
saved a tremendous, amount of

promising.

other day, one/of THE NEws-LETTER staff heard from the lips of Karl

glances at that sole oasis in the
desert of dullness—the sweet librarian of the stygian locks.
